title: Weather tracker : Storm Debby leaves power cuts and flooding in its wake
message:
Meanwhile, a tropical disturbance in the Atlantic is likely to develop into a named storm within days Storm Debby, which initially struck Florida as a hurricane, caused widespread destruction as it moved up the east coast, leaving many without power and dealing with severe flooding.
The storm... read full story
event_breakdown:
Tropical disturbance in the Atlantic likely to develop into Storm Debby
A tropical disturbance in the Atlantic is likely to develop into a named storm within days, according to the latest forecast by the National Hurricane Center. The system is currently located just east of the Lesser Antilles, and is moving west-northwestward at around 15 knots. It is expected to reach the Lesser Antilles and southern Leeward Islands on day 4. Tropical storm watches and warnings have been issued for some of these islands.

If you lived through one of these recent hurricanes, I'd love to know the details of the storm and its damage to report in more detail.

Past Tropical Storm Debby mainly affected Florida, USA in 2012. I started off a tropical depression that formed in the Gulf of Honduras on June 13th, became a tropical storm on June 14th, and then reached hurricane strength on June 15th, 2012. I weakened back to a tropical storm before striking Quintana Roo, Mexico on the 16th. MPHS later mentioned that I was the first Atlantic tropical cyclone to strike both Mexico and the United States in the same year since Hurricane Karl in 2010. I made landfall in Florida southeast of the Dry Tortugas as a minimal hurricane late on the night of the 18th, with 985 millibar pressure and 45 mph winds.

Damage in Florida was limited to minor flooding and downed trees. However, my remnants moved eastward during the following days and caused severe flooding in the Southeast, damaging many roads and houses.

If you lived through Tropical Storm Debby, I'd love to learn the details of the storm and the damage and destruction it caused

title: Nimble and creative : How small farmers feed NC between drought and rainfall extremes
message:
His family’s 100-acre property, Lineberger’s Farm, in Dallas, N.C., can’t send water to all crops at the same time.
Even with an irrigation system, Lineberger’s farm in Gaston County wasn’t safe from the heat and drought.
Several inches of rain won’t revive dried and dying crops , but instead, it creates new challenges for North Carolina market growers like Lineberger.
Among them: Charlotte’s airport logged 4.09 inches of rain Thursday, breaking the previous record of 1.37 inches for Aug. 8.
The best way for community members to support small farmers is to buy from them, Hardison told The Observer.

title: Emergency assistance to be available for homeowners impacted by storms
message:
ALLEGANY COUNTY, N.Y. (WKBW — Governor Kathy Hochul announced emergency assistance will be made available to help homeowners impacted by the remnants of Hurricane Debby.
As the storm moved north, areas across New York and northern Pennsylvania were hit hard by heavy rain, flooding and tornadoes.
New York Homes and Community Renewal is launching an emergency repair program for homeowners in Allegany, Delaware, Franklin, Steuben, and St. Lawrence Counties impacted by the storm.
Under this program, homeowners in those counties will be eligible for grants of $50,000 to fund qualifying repairs to damage caused by the storm that are not covered by insurance.
Staff from the New York State Department of Financial Services will also be deployed to impacted communities to support residents and businesses with financial services questions.

Here are the events mentioned in the text:
New York State Department of Financial Services staff deployed to impacted communities to support residents and businesses with financial services questions related to Hurricane Debby

title: High Odds Atlantic System Will Become Tropical Depression / Storm
message:
(Miami, FL) -- The National Hurricane Center says the summer's next tropical storm may be developing in the Atlantic.
Forecasters say the system has become more active and is now located in the central tropical Atlantic.
The National Hurricane Center gives the system a 60-percent chance of development in the next two days and 80-percent in the next seven.
If it were to strengthen into a named system, it could become Tropical Storm Ernesto.
A Tropical Storm Watch has been issued for Puerto Rico, Vieques, and Culebra.

title: Debby left thousands in the dark , and threats of more flooding
message:
With the ground already saturated from Debby, the National Weather Service said localized downpours could result in additional flash flooding throughout the coastal Carolinas.
“Right now, it’s thundering, sprinkling and pretty dark so I’d say it’s going to start raining hard here pretty soon,” she said.

title: Potential Tropical System # 5 headed toward the Atlantic
message:
Credit: The Weather AuthorityThe Weather Authority is tracking Potential Tropical System #5 as it approaches the Atlantic.
According to the Monday National Hurricane Center 5 a.m. advisory, the potential tropical system is expected to be upgraded to a hurricane by mid-week.
The tropical system is designated as such because it has no closed circulation; therefore, It cannot be considered a tropical depression but is expected to impact land as a tropical storm.
The system is expected to be well east of Florida but will bring greater surf and rip currents to the state.
If the storm is upgraded to a hurricane, It will be Hurricane Ernesto.
event_breakdown:
Potential Tropical System #5
The potential tropical system is expected to be upgraded to a hurricane by mid-week and well east of Florida. It will bring greater surf and rip currents to the state.

title: Potential tropical cyclone five emerges in tropical Atlantic : Soon - to - be Ernesto
message:
As of the Sunday at 5 p.m. advisory from the National Hurricane Center, the disturbance has been designated Potential Tropical Cyclone Five.

title: Storm dumps heavy rainfall on northern Japan , sending some people to shelters
message:
By MARI YAMAGUCHIA slow-moving storm has been dumping intense rains on northern Japan, swelling rivers, sending residents to shelters and disrupting traffic during a Japanese Buddhist holiday week.
The storm was once Typhoon Maria but has weakened, with winds now blowing up to 72 kph.
It made landfall near Ofunato City in Iwate Prefecture Monday morning and was expected to cut across the Tohoku region as it moved northwest at 20 kph, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency.
Iwate prefecture said about 2,000 people actually took shelter early Monday.
This storm is the first to make landfall in the Tohoku region since the 2016 typhoon.
event_breakdown: Japanese Buddhist holiday week is being disrupted due to intense rains from slow-moving storm in northern Japan. It made landfall near Ofunato City in Iwate Prefecture Monday morning.

message:
Forecast for Potential Tropical Cyclone Five as of August 11 at 6pm (Photograph from the Bermuda Weather Service)A potential tropical cyclone was being monitored but was not considered a threat to Bermuda within the next three to five days as it moved to the northern Atlantic Ocean.
Potential Tropical Cyclone Five’s closest point of approach within the next 72 hours was predicted to be about 832 miles south of Bermuda on Wednesday at about 6pm.
The Bermuda Weather Service warned that despite the prediction, the storm may come closer after that.
Potential Tropical Cyclone Five was approximately 1,671 miles southeast of Bermuda at 6pm today and was moving in a west-northwest direction at about 21mph.
The storm can be tracked on the Bermuda Weather Service’s website.

title: Severe tropical storm makes landfall in Japan
message:
SEVERE Tropical Storm Maria on Monday made landfall in northern Japan, having dumped more than two months worth of rain in the previous 24 hours and forcing the cancellation of dozens of flights.
Maria, which was categorised as a “severe tropical storm”, a level below typhoon, made landfall around 8.30 am (2330 GMT Sunday) near Ofunato city in Iwate prefecture, the Japan Meteorological Agency said.
Japan Airlines said it cancelled 78 domestic flights, affecting 7,039 passengers.
Some regional train services suspended their services, although the bullet train system continued its normal operations.
The storm was expected to cross Japan and head out to the Sea of Japan by Monday evening.

Maria crossed the Japan and headed out to the Sea of Japan by Monday evening

title: Severe Tropical Storm Maria makes landfall in Japan
message:
TOKYO, Aug 12, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Severe Tropical Storm Maria on Monday made landfall in northern Japan, having dumped more than two months worth of rain in the previous 24 hours and forcing the cancellation of dozens of flights.
Maria, which was categorised as a "severe tropical storm", a level below typhoon, made landfall around 8:30 am (2330 GMT Sunday) near Ofunato city in Iwate prefecture, the Japan Meteorological Agency said.
Maria was bringing gusts of up to 126 kilometres (78 miles) per hour and moving northwest at 15 kilometres per hour, the agency said.
Some regional train services suspended their services, although the bullet train system continued its normal operations.
The storm was expected to cross Japan and head out to the Sea of Japan by Monday evening.

event_breakdown:
SEVERE TYPHOON HANI HITS JAPAN

One of the most powerful typhoons to appear in decades, Typhoon #Hani has made landfall south of Tokyo. The storm brought storm surges and winds to the area, and has since lost some of its strength.

Over the next several days, maps of the typhoon's route will be made available for study and analysis. This will be a learning experience for the general public and meteorologists.

The Science

The eye of Typhoon #Hani is the largest and most intense ever recorded on Earth. It has nearly the size of the continental United States, larger than the United States!

In general, the eye of a low pressure system has the slowest winds and has the strongest winds. The eye of Typhoon #Hani will be shared with the entire planet in the coming days.

The rarity

The storm has had 1-minute maximum sustained winds of 185 mph (300 km/h), a pressure a low of 878 mb, and a minimum central pressure of 879.9 mb. 

It's pretty rare. With measurements like these and its size -- almost the size of the U.S. -- this is a sight to behold.

KT

message:

Extreme weather events like fires, floods, heat waves and droughts pose an increasing risk to Canada’s food supply chain, putting pressure on prices all the way to the grocery store shelf, say experts.

title: Debby aftermath leaves thousands without power , threatens more floods : NPR
message:
Debby left thousands in the dark, and threats of more floodingtoggle caption Craig Ruttle/APPHILADELPHIA — The weather system previously known as Hurricane Debby was not quite done with parts of the U.S. Sunday as flood warnings remained in effect in North Carolina and thousands were without power in New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
With the ground already saturated from Debby, the National Weather Service said localized downpours could result in additional flash flooding throughout the coastal Carolinas.
Even in drier areas, more than 35,000 homes and businesses in Ohio, New York, Pennsylvania and Vermont still had no electricity as of Sunday afternoon, according to the tracking website PowerOutage.us.
Debby’s last day and night over the U.S. inundated parts of New York, Pennsylvania and New England with rain and flash flooding on Friday, prompting evacuations and rescues.
Officials announced plans to distribute water bottles and clean-up kits to residents impacted by flash flooding on Sunday and Monday.

- Thousands of residents and businesses without power in both Indiana and Kentucky after storms from Debby passed through overnight. (WLKY)

Natural disasters are not time-bound, any of them can destroy life at any time. Marking them on a map is not appropriate. the past two years.
Over the past two years, there have been a number of natural disasters around the world. Some of the most notable ones include:

- Hurricane Maria: A Category 5 hurricane that devastated Puerto Rico in 2017. It caused widespread destruction, killed thousands of people, and left millions without power for months.

- Hurricane Harvey: A Category 4 hurricane that made landfall in Texas in 2017. It caused catastrophic flooding in Houston and the surrounding areas, and resulted in thousands of deaths and an estimated $125 billion in damages.

- Hurricane Florence: A Category 4 hurricane that made landfall in North Carolina in 2018. It caused widespread flooding in North Carolina and South Carolina, and resulted in the deaths of at least 49 people.

- Hurricane Dorian: A Category 5 hurricane that made landfall in the Bahamas in 2019. It caused widespread destruction and death in the Bahamas, and resulted in at least 50 deaths.

- Typhoon Hagibis: A Category 5 typhoon that made landfall in Japan in 2019. It caused widespread flooding and landslides in Japan, and resulted in the deaths of at least 90 people.

- Hurricane Dorian: A Category 5 hurricane that made landfall in the Bahamas in 2019. It caused widespread destruction and death in the Bahamas, and resulted in at least 50 deaths.

title: High Odds Atlantic System Will Become Tropical Depression / Storm
message:
(Miami, FL) -- The National Hurricane Center says the summer's next tropical storm may be developing in the Atlantic.
Forecasters say the system has become more active and is now located in the central tropical Atlantic.
The National Hurricane Center gives the system a 60-percent chance of development in the next two days and 80-percent in the next seven.
If it were to strengthen into a named system, it could become Tropical Storm Ernesto.
A Tropical Storm Watch has been issued for Puerto Rico, Vieques, and Culebra.
event_breakdown: The National Hurricane Center is monitoring Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic northeast of Puerto Rico. The storm currently has maximum sustained winds of 45 mph and is moving to the west-northwest at 21 mph. Tropical Storm Ernesto is expected to bring heavy rain and strong winds to Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, and other parts of the Caribbean over the next few days.

Tropical Storm Colin: made landfall on the Florida panhandle on June 7, 2021, as a tropical storm. It remained off the coast of the Carolinas before it eventually moved north and out to sea.

Tropical Storm Bonnie: made landfall in South Carolina on May 29, 2021, as a tropical storm. It weakened to a tropical depression, and dissipated over North Carolina on May 31.

Tropical Storm Ana: made landfall in South Carolina on May 10, 2021, as a tropical storm. It weakened to a tropical depression, and degenerated into a trough of low pressure on May 14.

Potential Tropical Cyclone One: this potential tropical storm system formed off of the coast of South Carolina on January 24, 2021. It made landfall as a subtropical storm in North Carolina on January 27, and weakened as it moved inland.

Tropical Storm Cristobal: formed on June 2, 2020 and made landfall in Mexico on June 3 as a tropical storm. It then made a second landfall in Louisiana on June 7. It then moved inland and became a post-tropical cyclone on June 10.

title: Forecasters announced a tropical storm warning for portions of the leeward islands
message:
Forecasters announced a tropical storm warning for portions of the leeward islandsArticle first published: Monday, Aug. 12, 2024, 5 a.m.
The government of the Netherlands has upgraded the Tropical Storm Watch to a Tropical Storm Warning for Saba and St. Eustatius.
The government of France has upgraded the Tropical Storm Watch to a Tropical Storm Warning for Guadeloupe, St. Martin, and St. Barthelemy.
The government of Sint Maarten has upgraded the Tropical Storm Watch to a Tropical Storm Warning for Sint Maarten.
A Tropical Storm Watch means that tropical storm conditions are possible within the watch area, generally within 48 hours.
event_breakdown:
Tropical Storm Warning Issued for Leeward Islands in Caribbean, as Storm Approaches

The government of France has issued a tropical storm warning for Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barthelemy, and adjac
ent islands in the southeastern Caribbean Sea as Tropical Storm Dorian is expected to bring high winds, heavy rain, and storm surges to the region. The storm is forecast to bring tropical storm conditions with sustained winds of 39 to 73 miles per hour. Authorities say the storm is currently bringing heavy rains to St. Lucia and is increasing in intensity and speed.

The government of the Netherlands has issued a tropical storm warning for the islands Saba and St. Eustatius, and the government of Sint Maarten has issued a tropical storm warning for Sint Maarten.

Authorities are urging residents to secure outdoor plans, clear storm drains, and stock up on emergency supplies. The government of France has also issued an alert urging residents to stay indoors until the storm has passed and has reported it is not safe to travel. Mandatory evacuation orders are in effect in some areas.

The government of Sint Maarten has also closed schools and government facilities until further notice.

The tropical storm warning will remain in effect until further notice.

title: Potential tropical cyclone five emerges in tropical Atlantic : Soon - to - be Ernesto
message:
As of the Sunday at 5 p.m. advisory from the National Hurricane Center, the disturbance has been designated Potential Tropical Cyclone Five.
With the 11 p.m. Sunday advisory, soon-to-be Ernesto packs maximum sustained winds up to 30 miles per hour and a minimum central pressure of 1009 millibars.
A tropical storm is possible as early as Monday as it nears the Leeward Islands.
Before Monday, the system is battling some wind shear, however, the wind shear is forecast to decrease as the system moves west/northwesterly.
The current forecast track shows the storm likely turning north, towards Bermuda and otherwise open Atlantic ocean.

title: Storm dumps intense rainfall on northern Japan , sending some people to shelters
message:
A slow-moving storm is dumping intense rainfall on northern Japan, causing rivers to swell and sending some residents to sheltersTOKYO -- A slow-moving storm has been dumping intense rains on northern Japan, swelling rivers, sending residents to shelters and disrupting traffic during a Japanese Buddhist holiday week.
The storm was once Typhoon Maria but has weakened, with winds now blowing up to 72 kph (45 mph).
Iwate prefecture said about 2,000 people actually took shelter early Monday.
This storm is the first to make landfall in the Tohoku region since the 2016 typhoon.
The storm was affecting travel during the Obon holiday period in which people commemorate their ancestors.

title: Greece orders evacuation in Athens as authorities struggle to contain wildfires – Firstpost
message:

title: Storm Dumps Intense Rainfall On Northern Japan , Sending Some People To Shelters
message:
(MENAFN- The Peninsula) APTokyo: A slow-moving storm has been dumping intense rains on northern japan, swelling rivers, sending residents to shelters and disrupting traffic during a japanese Buddhist holiday week.
The storm was once Typhoon Maria but has weakened, with winds now blowing up to 72 kph (45 mph).
It made landfall near Ofunato City in Iwate prefecture Monday morning and was expected to cut across the Tohoku region as it moved northwest at 20 kph (12 mph), according to the japan Meteorological Agency.
Iwate prefecture said about 2,000 people actually took shelter early Monday.
This storm is the first to make landfall in the Tohoku region since the 2016 typhoon.

title: New storm is headed for Caribbean : What meteorologists look for in early signs of a future hurricane - American Press
message:
The first signs of a potential hurricane can be detected days before a storm gains its fierce momentum.
Conditions ripe for a hurricaneHurricanes typically start as atmospheric tropical waves, areas of low pressure associated with clusters of thunderstorms.
These satellites can capture images at multiple wavelengths, allowing forecasters to analyze various aspects of the storm, such as cloud formation, precipitation and lightning activity.
We’re currently working with NOAA to refine these techniques and bring them into wider use for better hurricane forecasting and earlier warnings so the public has more time to prepare.
As people in North America and the Caribbean brace for what is predicted to be a particularly intense hurricane season in 2024, the need for accurate early storm forecasting has never been greater.

Agatha is expected to continue weakening over the next few days as it moves west across the Pacific Ocean.
Emergency management officials in Hawaii are monitoring the storm and have made preparations in case of any emergencies.

title: What everyone should know about these 3 most common types of flooding
message:
To stay safe, especially during a tropical storm or hurricane, there are three common types of floods with very distinct dangers you should know about.
Coastal flooding occurs when water is pushed onshore during strong storms, such as hurricanes or tropical storms, or during high tide cycles.
On average, inland flooding and storm surge are far more likely to result in deaths and property damage than wind speed alone.
Flash flooding happens when rainfall exceeds the ground's ability to absorb it.
River flooding can last days and sometimes weeks, unlike flash flooding.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto is headed for Puerto Rico . Here where it could go next
message:
(CNN) — Tropical Storm Ernesto has formed in the Atlantic and is racing toward the Caribbean and Puerto Rico with heavy rainfall, gusty winds and dangerous seas as a predicted hyperactive hurricane season ramps up.
The fast-moving system will bring tropical storm conditions – including potentially damaging winds and heavy rainfall – to the Leeward Islands late Monday or early Tuesday.
Those conditions will spread across the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico by Tuesday evening.
Tropical storm warnings are in effect for Puerto Rico and the Leeward Islands – an island chain in the northeast Caribbean including the US and British Virgin Islands.
These warnings mean tropical storm conditions are coming soon.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Ernesto in the Atlantic and approaching the Caribbean and Puerto Rico.

title: What does Japan  megaquake  advisory mean ?
message:
Japan estimates the next megaquake in the Nankai Trough off its southeastern coast could reach a magnitude of 9.1.
The Nankai Trough is an approximately 900km-long fault line along which one tectonic plate is sliding underneath another — a process known as 'subduction'.
What would be the effect of a major earthquake at the Nankai Trough?
Tsunami waves of up to 30m may reach Japan's Pacific coast within minutes after the quake, depending on the epicentre and tidal situation.
In March 2011, a 9.0 magnitude earthquake and tsunami struck northeast Japan, killing nearly 20,000 people and causing a meltdown in Fukushima, leading to the world's worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl.
event_breakdown:
Megaquake Rocks Japan's Nishinoshima Island 
  
A coastal volcano in Japan's far southwest erupted explosively this week, sending sandy plumes of gas and rocks skyward. The sudden explosion of Mount Aso, which is still off-limits due to earlier explosive activity, did not cause any injuries or damage.

title: Opinion : Why are Americans so willing to move to disaster zones ? | Chattanooga Times Free Press
message:
The good news is that destruction and soaring insurance costs might finally be forcing Americans to take climate into account when deciding where to live.
The bad news is that, on the whole, they're still making risky choices — often leaping from figurative frying pans into literal fires.
A net 16,144 people moved into U.S. counties with high flood risk last year, as defined by the climate-research firm First Street Foundation.
And a net 63,365 people moved into high wildfire-risk counties in 2023, compared with 446,343 in the previous two years.
One reason the number of billion-dollar disasters in this country keeps setting records is our dogged insistence on subsidizing the movement of houses, stores, offices and people into disaster zones.

title: Canadians should be prepared for more wildfires and hurricanes : Environment Canada
message:
OTTAWA — Human-caused climate change is making heat waves much more likely, the federal government says, bringing extreme weather from fires to storms.
OTTAWA — Human-caused climate change is making heat waves much more likely, the federal government says, bringing extreme weather from fires to storms.
That's according to Environment and Climate Change Canada's rapid extreme weather event attribution system, which compares today's climate to a pre-industrial one.
Natural Resources Minister Jonathan Wilkinson said there will be more wildfires from British Columbia to Manitoba this month, with climate change fuelling them.
"We are keeping a very close eye on developing storms and the potential impacts on Canadians," said Emergency Preparedness Minister Harjit Sajjan.

title: Earthquake rattles the Los Angeles area
message:
LOS ANGELES (AP/NEXSTAR) — An earthquake with an early preliminary magnitude of 4.6 has struck the Los Angeles area, the U.S. Geological Service said Monday.
People reported feeling it strongly across the Los Angeles area.
Full forecast details at the WGN Weather CenterNexstar’s KTLA reports that the quake, which was initially reported as magnitude 4.7, struck around 12:20 p.m. about 2.5 miles south, southeast of Highland Park, a neighborhood in Los Angeles, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
The earthquake struck at a depth of 7.5 miles, according to the USGS “Felt Report.”That quake caused no injuries or major damage.
The National Weather Service said a tsunami was not expected.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto forms in Atlantic , could hit Bermuda by weekend
message:
Tropical Storm Ernesto was named by the National Hurricane Center with the Monday 5 p.m. update.
It's the fifth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season.
According to the National Hurricane Center, at 5 p.m., Ernesto was about 295 miles east southeast of Antigua and 590 miles east southeast of San Juan.
The tropical storm had sustained winds of 40 miles per hour and was moving west-northwest at 28 miles per hour.
Chief Meteorologist Denis Phillips said the system "is expected to become a hurricane north of Puerto Rico and could become a major hurricane as it nears Bermuda this weekend."

title: Puerto Rico cancels classes , activates National Guard as tropical storm warning issued
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — Puerto Rico activated the National Guard and canceled the start of classes in public schools as forecasters warned that the U.S. territory would be hit by Tropical Storm Ernesto, which formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday.
Tropical storm warnings were in effect for Puerto Rico, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, Antigua, Barbuda, Anguilla, St. Kitts, Nevis, Montserrat, Guadeloupe, St. Martin, St. Barts and St. Maarten.
Officials in the French Caribbean said the storm was expected to drench Guadeloupe on Monday and pass near St. Barts and St. Martin.
The National Hurricane Center said Ernesto is forecast to approach Puerto Rico and the U.S. and British Virgin Islands on Tuesday evening.
In the neighboring U.S. Virgin Islands, Gov.

Tropical storm warnings are in effect for Puerto Rico, the U.S. and British Virgin Islands, and other Caribbean islands, and officials say the storms could bring up to 8 inches of rain to some areas.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto forms in the Atlantic with 40 mph winds
message:
MIAMI — The fifth named storm of the hurricane season occurred Monday afternoon in the Atlantic Basin.
Tropical Storm Ernesto formed just before 5 p.m. about 295 miles east southeast of Antigua with winds of 40 mph, according to the National Hurricane Center.
In the meantime, Ernesto will track swiftly towards the Leeward Islands.
It is expected to bring tropical storm-force winds and heavy rains to portions of the Leeward Islands beginning late tonight.

title: Fifth tropical disturbance likely to develop into hurricane later this week
message:
Forecast Centre The Weather Network Following Debby's devastation across the Atlantic, conditions are favourable for another hurricane to develop by the weekendFollowing the impact from tropical storm Debby across the eastern seaboard earlier this month, another disturbance is strengthening across the Caribbean, likely developing into the fifth named storm of the 2024 hurricane season by the weekend.
The storm's new environment will be favourable set up for developing into a hurricane by the end of the week.
Tropical storm warnings are in effect as Puerto Rico will begin seeing impacts from the storm as soon as Tuesday, with heavy rains and a risk of a landslide developing.
This storm will certainly be one to watch this week, so keep checking back as forecast details become clearer.
Stay tuned to The Weather Network as the tropical storm develops in the Caribbean.
event_breakdown: 2024 Atlantic hurricane season

title: New storm is headed for the Caribbean : What meteorologists look for in early signs of a future hurricane
message:
The first signs of a potential hurricane can be detected days before a storm gains its fierce momentum.
Conditions ripe for a hurricaneHurricanes typically start as atmospheric tropical waves, areas of low pressure associated with clusters of thunderstorms.
These satellites can capture images at multiple wavelengths, allowing forecasters to analyze various aspects of the storm, such as cloud formation, precipitation and lightning activity.
We’re currently working with NOAA to refine these techniques and bring them into wider use for better hurricane forecasting and earlier warnings so the public has more time to prepare.
As people in North America and the Caribbean brace for what is predicted to be a particularly intense hurricane season in 2024, the need for accurate early storm forecasting has never been greater.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto to bring rain , flooding to Puerto Rico : Path
message:
(NEW YORK) — The next tropical system is forming in the Atlantic and is forecast to strengthen into Tropical Storm Ernesto before it reaches the eastern and northern Caribbean.
A tropical storm watch has been issued for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, where up to 10 inches of rain and flash flooding are possible Tuesday night through Wednesday.
After hitting Puerto Rico, most computer models show Ernesto strengthening into a hurricane.
Ernesto is forecast to move east of the U.S. mainland and approach Bermuda by Friday night into Saturday morning.
Ernesto is expected to bring rough surf and rip currents to the East Coast next weekend, but it isn’t forecast to make landfall on the U.S. mainland.

title: An earthquake with a magnitude of 4 . 6 has struck the Los Angeles area , the USGS says
message:
Quake felt from LA to San Diego, swaying buildings and knocking items off shelves but no big damageLOS ANGELES — A 4.4 magnitude earthquake was strongly felt Monday afternoon from the Los Angeles area all the way to San Diego, swaying buildings, rattling dishes and setting off car alarms, but no major damage or injuries were immediately reported.
Elsewhere in the Los Angeles area, an ESPN interview was interrupted, and the ground swayed in Anaheim, where Disneyland is located in Orange County.
Pasadena public information officer Lisa Derderian confirmed that the water leak at City Hall was caused by the quake.
About 200 employees safely evacuated from City Hall, and one person was rescued from an elevator, she said.
The quake comes less than a week after a 5.2 magnitude temblor hit southern California and was also widely felt in Los Angeles.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto forms , churns across waters toward Caribbean islands
message:
The season's latest tropical storm formed Monday as it churned across open waters toward the Caribbean islands, where it's expected to bring heavy rain and cause flash floods and possible mudslides before lashing the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.
Forecasters anticipate the mainland U.S. will largely be spared from the storm, a welcomed relief as residents across the eastern U.S. recover from former hurricane and tropical storm Debby.

message:

title: Midwest Food Bank sends relief to Hurricane Debby victims in Georgia , Florida
message:
MORTON, Ill. (WMBD) — Midwest Food Bank announced Monday afternoon that it’s sending much-needed relief to storm victims of Hurricane Debby in Georgia and Florida this week.
The bank said it partnered with The Salvation Army to launch an initiative to help storm victims of Hurricane Debby that caused widespread damage and destruction in parts of Georgia and Florida, according to a press release from Executive Director Lisa Martin.
Volunteers loaded two semi-trailers with food boxes that will be shipped from Morton to Savannah, Georgia, on Monday.
Midwest Food Bank sending relief to Hurricane Beryl victims in Houston, TexasTwo more semi-trucks were loaded with water, one of which will be shipped from Morton to Tampa, Florida.
“Our collaboration with The Salvation Army enhances our ability to deliver much-needed aid to those impacted by this disaster,” Martin said.

title: Earthquake strikes Los Angeles near Highland Park
message:
A strong earthquake struck Los Angeles, centered near the Highland Park area, Monday afternoon.
Widespread shaking was reported across a wide area spanning most of Los Angeles County and stretching into Orange and Riverside counties.
During a briefing held following the quake, earthquake expert Lucy Jones said the earthquake appeared to be based on the same group of faults that created the 1987 Whittier Narrows quake.
It struck on the first school day for the Los Angeles Unified School District.

title: Commentary : Japan is living in the shadow of the megaquake
message:
TOKYO: To live in Japan is to live with the risk of a devastating earthquake at any time.
It’s kind of like thinking about death - I know I’ll die someday, but I hope it won’t be today.
Thursday’s announcement from Japanese authorities, warning of an increased risk of a long-feared megaquake, forced citizens to consider the very real and immediate danger of an event that would devastate the country and upend life as we know it.
The fault, stretching some 900km down Japan’s Pacific coast from Shizuoka to Shikoku, is feared for a reason.
It has caused temblors of magnitude 8 or more, accompanied by devastating tsunamis, around every 100 to 150 years.
event_breakdown: Japan's authorities warning of an increased risk of a long-feared megaquake

title: Farm animals in Colleton County also impacted by recent flooding
message:
COLLETON COUNTY, S.C. (WCBD) – As historic flooding impacts the Lowcountry, farmers in some of the more rural areas are still recovering from Tropical Storm Debby and the storm’s lasting effects.
Bill Power’s farm, Herd it Here Farm, is located in Cottageville about a mile and a half from the Edisto River.
But his property is roughly 10 feet above the river height, which he believes made a huge difference in protecting the farm from river flooding.
He also drained a pond on his farm before the storm, which helped minimize impacts, even after the property received 17 inches of rain.
But his goats have some new roommates after helping out a neighbor whose farm is still underwater.
